reviews.review:
Introduction

Half-Life 2 takes place 20 or so years after Half-Life. You (again) play as Mr. Freeman, waking up after a stasis put in by The G-man. You find yourself in a completely new world, one overruled by Zombies, Combine, and Authoritarian Leadership. You must defeat the Combine in hopes to every see freedom again.

The Bad

Half-Life 2 definitely has its flaws, a lot of the time, the first half of a new chapter will either be really good, or really bad, and then the second half will be really good, or really bad. This mainly applies to the stages "Water Hazard", "Ravenholm", and "Highway 17". All three of these are regarded to be the worst out of the Half-Life 2 stages, and rightfully so. The second half, or first half, of these stages, can be a mixed bag. Other things I had troubles with the game was the enemies AI, overuse of Med Kits and HEV packs, and overall sometimes poor or confusing level design. With that being said, there are many good things about this game as well.

The Good

Half-Life 2 by far has some of the best action in a game i have ever seen. It at times can be very fast paced, allowing for some moments of pure dopamine rushes, such as getting a Phat meat shot on a Combine Soldier using a shotgun. The acting and NPC dialogue is also great as well. I honestly felt super intrigued by the worlds atmosphere and lore. The pacing of the game is also regarded as being the best, allowing moments of thinking, reflecting, and catching your breath from time to time. The opening of the game, point intersection, really takes a hold of you and openly shows you what kind of world you're in. There is propaganda everywhere, and Combine Soldiers shoving and ruling over citizens lives. Weapons and combat in the game is also extremely good, if you push (Q), you can  switch back from the previous weapon you have used before, allowing for some amazing combos to deal damage as quickly, and precisely as possible. Puzzles and level design in most areas are also very well done. Even if you don't want this game for the story and lore, the action and music really drive it home, even in sections of the game I didn't like to well. 

Closing

Overall, I say this game gets a 9/10. I mostly had fun with this game, a little less than the base Half-Life, but it is hard to beat a already amazing game. I truly think this game is worth the by, even if it has its moments of difficulty for the player. Either if you buy this game for the story, or game play, I can assure you will have fun.

Half-Life and Half-Life 2 (especially HL2) are the reasons that I play video games at all.

I came to PC gaming pretty late in life (I was probably 50 at the time), and Half-Life 2 was the first game I saw and played on the PC.  I was immediately hooked.  Even with all the advancements since, what, 2004 (?), HL2 still ranks as one of the best, if not the best, of all time. 

As you can see, I've played it for 121 hours (which, since it takes ~7-10 hours to play through, means I've replayed it 12 times, or more (I've lost count).  By far that is the most replaying of any game... for me, at least.  Obviously, I'm not including co-op games like Borderlands 2, and the Left4Deads, because their multi-player qualities make them very replayable. For a single-player game, like HL2, 12 replays is...  a lot.  Again, that's in my opinion, of course.

Can't wait for Half Life: Alyx...

- s.west

Will always be my baby after 14 years

Half-Life 2 is honestly my favorite game of all time. Valve did such a great job with everything, from the story to the levels themselves. To be honest, I'm not sure where we'd be without this game; it's nearly perfect from every angle as far as I see it. And now that there's a new game in the series coming out, I couldn't be happier to see that Valve actually hasn't forgotten about it.
